answers.answer: Why not start by posting your "optimal" T4 and T3 results, with reference ranges, since ranges vary lab to lab and have to come from your own reports?  Also, please tell us if the T4 and T3 were Free T4 and Free T3 or if they were Total T4 and Total T3... They aren't the same tests and don't give the same information...A fluctuating TSH really means nothing, since TSH can vary by as much as 75% over the course, of a single day and is affected by many variables, other than thyroid hormones.  Free T4 and Free T3 are the best indicators of actual thyroid status.

Most of us find that we feel best with FT4 at about mid range; your latest FT4 was 62% of its range, which is higher than recommended.  We also find that we feel best with FT3 in the upper half to upper third of its range; your last FT3 was 83% of its range, which is also higher than recommended...You should make sure you get FT3 every time you get FT4 and TSH tested, since FT3 correlates best with symptoms.Even though your TSH is fluctuating and has been at the top of the range, your FT3 and FT4 are borderline hyper and there's no reason to think you need replacement thyroid hormones, but of course, you should monitor your levels periodically.Have you been tested for thyroid antibodies to determine if you have Hashimoto's?  Hashimoto's is an autoimmune thyroid condition in which antibodies destroy the thyroid... The antibody tests you need are Thyroid Peroxidase Antibodies (TPOab) and Thyroglobulin Antibodies (TgAb).It would seem that your weight gain and other hypo-like symptoms may be coming from the PCOS, which is often accompanied by insulin resistance, also known as pre-diabetes.  A diet, low in simple carbohydrates and higher in healthful fats may help you lose weight.  The diarrhea, anxiety, etc may come from high thyroid hormone levels.
